displayed_text: Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it? Doctor: V as in Victor. Patient: Oh ARV7 and thought that you know there were some possibilities there. The liver pathology at Hospital B he wasn’t real keen on and so he had the samples sent up here. Doctor: And they confirmed that it’s prostate cancer. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah, rather than liver cancer, yes, and that’s kind of where we stand. Family Member: The only difference is Dr G___ was emphatic about having T__ call him after he had visited with you because he would like to know what you had to say.

Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping.

Patient: But if you’re not ready today I can get that back home too. Doctor: -bone weakness. Yeah you can. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: With a prescription. I was reading up on the prostate cancer in the bone and they recommended not – a diet low in calcium for that. Do you know anything about that? Doctor: No I think for a while people were maxing out and taking crazy high amounts of calcium. So that is not recommended because they actually found a worse outcome with that. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So the typical you don’t want to get past fifteen hundred a day. Family Member: Yeah they were saying that was too much. Doctor: For some reason that was the top – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: - but yeah so no, no.

Patient: Right. Doctor: but I don’t want to be on the back end because you you know in the story that you didn’t share Patient: Yeah. Doctor: with all the stuff related to what you’ve been doing with Dr. P____. Patient: Right. Doctor: That’s a whole ‘nother situation as you know Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that is not immediately making us have to worry from a treatment standpoint. Patient: Right. Doctor: But the rest of you, if I want to get better control of this situation – Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: - it’s better that we start thinking about doing this medicine. Patient: Mm, hmm. So what else, what is the other um other than the weakness, the tiredness?

Patient: Did you get your certificate? Doctor: My certificate? Patient: From the U_______. Doctor: I did! How did you know that? (pause) Patient: I – You you want me to be the best patient you’ve got, I… Patient: I have to know all that stuff. Doctor: Thank you. I’m now officially the Rudi Ansbacher academic scholar at U______. Patient: Good for you. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: This this comes from The Art of War by Doctor: Oh man! Patient: Always occupy… Doctor: That was in the battleship movie.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm.

Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively. Doctor: Well, I think if I was going to choose between those two things, and I had the means to choose between the two, I would choose the PSMA. Patient: Yes, I know. Doctor: Yeah. I mean this is really just antidotal for me for two patients. They’ve got other things in between that could have nothing to do with testosterone. We’re, we’re trying to make as much, we’ve got somebody interested in a small trial to test the idea, but I, I really, I wouldn’t be that confident. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Like you said, geez, which has the better chance? Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just- Doctor: I mean I think we’ll do that uh you know really quickly if that’s what you wanted to do. So I can work on that this week. Patient: Yeah. I appreciate that. Doctor: To find out - I’ll also see what I can find out about this test I mentioned then. Patient: Oh for the marker? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll just give us some information about uh uh you know we’ve learned that folks who have that marker, the cancer tends to be way more aggressive in addition to being less sensitive a hormone treatment, there may also be a marker, a change in the cancer that’s made it more aggressive. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. So it works on your testicles which produce the testosterone and it makes them stop producing testosterone. So people have like menopause type symptoms. Mm? Family Member: So you’re going to use Lupron? Doctor: Yes, exactly. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So we use Lupron Family Member: Shots? Doctor: Mhm. So people get hot flashes. People get low libido, can have erectile dysfunction. And sometimes your testicles will actually get smaller. People can feel more fatigued you sometimes get some weight gain. There can be some cardiovascular like, um like changes in your cholesterol. Let me remind myself though, what other medicines are you on now? Family Member: Cinepro for high blood pressure. Cinepro 1800. Um.. Doctor: Is it potassium? Patient: Potassium.

Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes? Doctor: Just let us know. Patient: Okay. It won’t take long; I just want to absorb everything. Then I get back. Okay. Doctor: Um, R___ do you have any other questions? Family Member 1: Just the sequence of things. The hormone therapy and the chemo therapy and Zytiga. Are they all started at the same time? Doctor: Uh, pretty much, yeah. Um and we could start the hormone shot any time. Patient: I’m scheduled. Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Okay.That’s yours Okay and this is Doctor: That is a problem as is the … ORIOLE trial. Patient: Okay. And, this is for me? Doctor: That is your copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: As is this diagram Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you have any other questions that arise immediately that you want to discuss? Patient: Uh, and you may not be able to are you gonna be able to check when Doctor: Yeah so that’s a good question. So um there’s an easy answer to that and there’s a more easy answer to that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The easy answer is if you ever develop symptoms from your cancer. For example, if the cancer has spread to your bone or if the cancer in the lymph node causing a blood obstruction. stop the

Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain.

Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work. Doctor: Yes we did. Patient: Okay. Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So when when when can we start taking the pill? Doctor: So what happens is I go through the insurance. They go through a third party vendor. So Diplomate, CVS Caremark, whatever one your insurance you know sends me to. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then they mail it to your house Patient: Okay. Doctor: and then when you get it you take four pills a day. Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: If you can, you just call us, call K__ or W__ and go hey we got the medicine Patient: Right.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I see. Doctor: All the things it does downstream without the ball. We’ve been testing that as part of this trial. So I need to dig into the group that’s testing and find out are you one of those guys that was positive? Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you were positive, that would mean pretty strongly that we shouldn’t try more hormone treatments. You need to be positive for that to go on this immune trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh they’re looking for folks who might have more aggressive hormone insensitive cases. So I’m, I’m going to do that this week just to find out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so I think that’s a trial. Uh I’m trying to think. I mean, we, we had a, I’m just thinking of one of the study nurses. There’s also some evidence that folks who uh have been on enzalutamide like you are, there was a group that started giving people immune therapy with enzalutamide, even though the enzalutamide was not working. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They kept them on the enzalutamide and added this immune drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And they had occasional patients who have very dramatic effects. Uh probably about twenty-five percent of the patients they treat. So we have a trial. I’ve got to figure out if we can finesse it because you’re not on enzalutamide any more.

Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that. Doctor: So -. Family Member: Does insurance do anything with this? I mean, do they consider you a risk? Are you -- Doctor: I don’t know. Um, you, you, they’re going to need to talk with their doctors. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. If they were negative, there’s – you know, your grandkids are – it, it can’t skip over it – so, if your sons or daughter is negative (coughs) Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Unless their – Family Member: Their husband has it – Doctor: Unless their husband or wife has it. Family Member: Right. Well the one that has, um, the children, is in the military. So, she has access to really good medical care and probably could do this at little cost or, I don’t know. Patient: Well. Who cares about the cost for Christ’s sake? Family Member: Well, no, I mean, but she has good medical care. So. Doctor: Well, again, I could, we could even do the test we just did, um, Family Member: It’s easy for her to get tested for anything. You know what I mean? If she wants to.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: That one doesn’t care. Patient: Right. If everything looks good, I’d like to come back on the nineteenth. Doctor: Right. So, if we communicate by MyChart or I_ and I will communicate with you about stopping the drugs, if you decide, but I want you to take a look at it Patient: Okay. Doctor: More, more. Patient: Yeah, perfect. Doctor: And again, most of the time, a clock starts ticking the day you take your last dose. Patient: Okay. And so, I, do -- Doctor: So, when you guys are driving back and you say, you know, “I’m gonna stop.” You just stop. You know, if you need to get more of the TGF-A, I’ll let I_ know. Patient: Now, this one here. It looks like, um, the only thing that I’d have to stop would be the Lilly drug, right? Doctor: Ummm. Any Enzalutamide, I believe. You’d stay on your hormone shot.
